ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Validity of Consent Fee)


    1. Mr Ong Teng Cheong asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board the reasons and justification for imposing a Consent Fee of 2% based on the total estimated cost of proposed renovation or alteration works to be carried out to leased Housing and Development Board properties; and whether such levy is legally valid.

Column: 816



    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, a 2% fee was levied, where Housing and Development Board land is leased to industries, for extensions or alterations to their premises. The fees were collected more as an increase in the premium because of the more intensive usage of the land rather than to defray processing costs. The charge is valid as it is provided for in a clause of the lease. The fees are not charged for shop premises which are on rental nor do they apply to extensions to residential properties sold. These fees have been waived for industries for this year in view of the present economic conditions.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1975 TO 31ST MARCH, 1976



    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [5th Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head S (cont.) -

    The following amendment stood in the names of Messrs Ng Kah Ting, Sim Boon Woo and Ong Teng Cheong:-

    (7) That the sum to be allocated for Head S be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CDD 1107.

Column: 818



    The Chairman: Mr Ng Kah Ting is not here. Mr Sim Boon Woo.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): I am not speaking, Sir.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong (Kim Keat): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head S be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CDD 1107.

    Sir, I was wondering whether the Minister concerned would recall - if he were to refer to page 235 and page 244 of the Main and Development Estimates for the Financial Year 1974-75 - that there was, in fact, no indication at all that the function of the Development Control Division of the Planning Department would be transferred. But as soon as the last Estimates were approved by this House last year, a Ministry circular dated 28th March, 1974, was issued advising that the function of the Development Control Division was to be transferred from the Planning Department to the Building Control Division under the overall charge of the Assistant Director (Building Control) of the Public Works Department, with effect from 1st April, 1974. No reason had been given for the transfer of functions. But one thing was clear. It was a hasty decision because it had rendered the last Main and Development Estimates out of date as soon as it was approved in this House.

    I am not against the transfer of the Development Control Division to the Building Control Division of the PWD. In fact, I thought it would be a rather good idea if it could cut down red tape by amalgamating the two Divisions, both having very closely related functions regulating almost all aspects of the physical development in the Republic. Although almost a year has lapsed, it is noted that there is still an obvious lack of communication and coordination between the two Divisions within the same Department. It is not unusual to realise that one Division is not aware of the decision or action taken by the other Division and members of the public involved are often required to transmit information on their behalf. This has

Column: 819

resulted in unnecessary loss of valuable time to both the Department and the public.

    I wonder if the Minister is aware of this and whether immediate remedial measures would be introduced to rectify the situation in order to achieve the intended objective of the transfer of the function or part of the function of the Planning Department to the Public Works Department. I am sure the Minister will agree that the sooner the working relationship within the Department is improved, the more expeditiously and effectively it will serve the public.

    Another point that I would like to speak under this subhead is on demolition enforcement. It is noted that the demolition enforcement policy has been rather inconsistent and that the action taken by the Department has been rather unpredictable. There were complaints that stringent action had been taken against those who had difficulty in communicating with officers of the Department. There were also complaints that swift action had been taken against those members of the public who had innocently put up minor extensions and repairs, as have already been raised by the Members for Jurong and Paya Lebar. And sometimes even awnings erected over windows to keep off the weather had to be demolished at short notice, while other unauthorised erections had been allowed to remain. If this is not inconsistency, what is? What about unauthorised erections put up by Government agencies or statutory bodies? What action has been taken against them?

    An hon. Member: Nothing.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: I hope the Minister will not ask me to name the unauthorised erections put up by Government agencies. I am not suggesting that the Demolition Enforcement Department should be more stringent. On the contrary, I am suggesting that they should extend their understanding and

Column: 820

reasonable attitude to the public, as they have to Government agencies.

    I wish to join my colleagues in urging the Department officers to adopt a more humane and reasonable attitude in the performance of their duty in order to minimise grievances and hardship to the people. The public is aware arid recognises the powerful arm of the law. But there is nothing to be gained by adopting a harsh and rigid approach. Sometimes economic loss to our nation is the result instead.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, some teething problems are inevitable in the early stages of the integration of the Development Control Division with the Building Control Division. Most of these problems have now been resolved, but if members of the public encounter inconveniences because the departments do not function efficiently, they are requested to write in to my Ministry.

2.45 p.m.

    The Division's demolition enforcement officer by the very nature of his work attracts an impression of harshness and rigidity, while in effect he is merely discharging the unpleasant duties of his job which is really not an easy one. Actual physical demolition represents the culmination of very careful consideration and decision by the Division's officers in every case. Demolition is resorted to when all avenues for the possible regularisation or toleration of the unauthorised structures are exhausted. Members of the public should not erect unauthorised structures in the hope of escaping official detection. Building procedures have been streamlined, but relaxed wherever possible. It is not so difficult to obtain permission before carrying out building activities. If there are incidents where officers in the department have been rude or intolerant, Members are invited to bring such incidents to my notice and appropriate action will be taken.

Column: 821



    The policy on unauthorised erections is quite clear. Under the Building Control Act, all structures which are erected without the approval of the Building Authority or in contravention of the Building regulations are unauthorised, and the Authority has power to demolish.

    As for statutory boards, there has been no occasion when the Division has taken action against unauthorised erections. Besides, the fact that the Government is exempted from the Building Control Act, all Government buildings are scrutinised by the Planning Authorities and there is nothing to gain from erecting unauthorised structures. Statutory bodies are required to obtain planning permission and building approval for their buildings.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, in view of the Minister's reply, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The Chairman: Haji Mohd. Ariff is not here. Mr P. Govindaswamy, amendment (8).

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head S be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CDE 1107*. (*The same amendment stood in the name of Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi).

    Sir, I believe that several trees in parks and along roads are slanting dangerously and appear to fall at any time. Can the department concerned plan a programme to cut them down so as to avoid unnecessary damage to property and lives?

    It is also believed that a major park is to be opened in Marine Parade and in various parts of the country. Can the Minister elaborate these programmes?

    Again, lighting and parking facilities in some of our present parks are inadequate. Can the department concerned kindly look into this matter in order to improve the situation?

    Mr Barker: Sir, slanting trees are not necessarily dangerous. The condition of

Column: 822

the tree depends not only on the soundness of its roots but also on whether its trunk has suffered decay. But the Parks and Recreation Division does carry out periodic inspections of old trees. Those trees that are found dangerous or likely to fall down are cut down.

    The Member wants to know more about parks. The East Coast Park of 350 acres, or 140 hectares, of reclaimed land with a five-mile shoreline stretching from Tanjong Rhu to Bedok is being developed into a park and recreational area. The area between the Singapore Swimming Club and the Housing and Development Board Marine Parade Estate has already been turfed and planted. A six-hectare, or 15-acre, swimming lagoon, which in terms of surface area is equivalent to about 40 Olympic-sized swimming pools and capable of accommodating about 6,000 people at a time, is being constructed by the Ministry of the Environment and scheduled for completion in early 1976. Other facilities will include footpaths, car parks, cycle tracks, changing rooms, hawker and food centres, and even a golf driving range. Camping sites will be provided and chalets built by the Housing and Urban Development Co. (Pte.) Ltd, for rental to the public. An orchard is being developed in an area of about four hectares, or 10 acres, behind the Chinese Swimming Club. There are also plans to build a tennis complex, an indoor recreational centre and even a bicycle station.

    I wonder whether that satisfies the Member or whether he desires more information on other parks.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I am satisfied with the Minister's reply, and I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head S be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CEA 1107.

Column: 823



    The Planning Department, which is the nerve centre for all planning matters in Singapore and a very important section in the Ministry of National Development, was split into two in April last year. One section of the Planning Department was to deal with the Master Plan and long-term planning, and the other section known as the Development Control Division is to operate under the PWD. As a result of the split, the position of the professional planners is not clear. The morale of the officers is low. They even fear to talk to members of the public, who from time to time seek preliminary advice prior to submission of formal applications to the Development Control Division.

    In overseas countries development control is always part of the Planning Department for the efficient operation of planning control. What was the reason behind the split? Is the separation going to be permanent?

    I would like to know how many resignations have taken place since the separation? Are the planners who are in the profession happy with this separation?

    I would also like to know whether officers of both divisions are eligible to apply for a senior post when a vacancy arises. At the moment, I believe that promotion to a senior post is confined to officers of the particular division where the vacancy exists. This has caused great dissatisfaction among the planners because of frustration and lack of promotion prospects and incentives. This was what I was given to understand from a disappointed planner who has since resigned, and as you know, Sir, it is difficult to recruit planners. I would request the Minister to make a review of this important division.

    Sir, I would like to know what is really happening to the former Raffles Institution site. I believe the former historic building had to be demolished to make way for urban renewal, and that a tall building will be built at the site so as to keep up with other tall buildings

Column: 824

in the city area. But instead of the tall building as expected, the site has been converted into a car park. Just imagine, a historic Raffles Institution building demolished for a mere car park! May I know why the Planning Department had second thoughts on the project in this important area?

    Again, another precious piece of land, the former Gemini Chit Fund site at Bras Basah Road, has been converted into the best plot for growing lalang. While there is acute shortage of land in the city area for development, we find this place lying idle for growing lalang. I hope the Planning Department will not be so fickle in its functions. Either we develop according to schedule or leave the place to our citizens who are occupying the land. Sir, can the Minister give an explanation for these anomalies?

    Sir, I have received many complaints about development in my constituency. Building approvals have been granted for some areas in Wallich Street, which is indeed very good for the uplift of Anson constituency. However, I would like to know why there is some discrimination in the Tras Street area where building approvals have been granted for a certain section but not granted for another section. Can the Minister explain the policy of granting building approvals?

    Mr Barker: Sir, the decision to split the long-term planning and development control functions was made in the interest of improving efficiency. Prior to April, 1974, the Development Control Division which deals with private development applications was part of the Planning Department, whilst the Building Control Division which deals with building plan approvals was part of the Public Works Department. Logically, the Development Control Division and the Building Control Division should be integrated into one unit because building plan approvals are tied up with planning approvals and vice versa.

    Master Plan and long-range planning, on the other hand, embody a wider area of planning control and are best left as a separate department. This will save

Column: 825

the long-range planners from being bogged down with the routine development applications which entail time-consuming interviews with architects and developers; follow-up action on planning approvals, attendance at hearing appeals and taking enforcement action for contraventions of planning permission.

    With the separation of functions, the Development Control planners are able to spend full-time on the day-to-day applications received from the private sector and are thus able to offer better service to developers and architects. The Planning Department planners in turn are able to do a more thorough and uninterrupted job at long-range and block-planning and to concentrate on public development projects.

3.00 p.m.

    Since the transfer, there have been three resignations of planners, two from the Planning Department and one from the Development Control Division. All three have resigned for personal reasons. Their resignations had nothing to do with the transfer of the departmental functions. It is not understood why the Member for Anson should think that the morale of the planners is very low. Additional senior posts have been created since the promotion, and the promotional prospects of planners in both the Planning Department and the Development Control Division have improved. Vacancies of senior posts are now open to officers of both sections.

    With regard to the former Raffles Institution site and the Gemini Chit Fund site at Bras Basah Road, I do not understand why the Member for Anson should blame the Planning Department for the absence of development. It is not only planning approval that leads to a building. A lot depends upon the owners. In the case of Raffles Institution, it belongs to the Development Bank of Singapore. For their own reasons they have postponed the construction of the building. The proposal has been temporarily shelved. At one time it was because of the shortage of skilled labour and building materials.

Column: 826

The project has since been revived and the architects, I understood, are now proceeding with the detailed planning. The site would not be left as a car park-cum-school field as it is now, but a 70-storey building is coming up and it should satisfy the Member in due course.

    The Gemini Chit Fund site was granted planning approval in 1968 for a hotel/commercial building. This permission was cancelled in 1970 because of non-compliance with planning conditions. A new proposal for the erection of a 24-storey hotel/commercial building was approved in April, 1973. The developers have requested that the project be deferred because of the current economic situation. Since this site belongs to a private developer, the Division cannot compel the developer to proceed if he is unable to do so. However, every encouragement is being given for the revival of the proposal.

    It is difficult to reply to the Member's last question without details of the site being given. He refers to new buildings being allowed in Wallich Street. Perhaps he is referring to the one at the junction of Wallich Street and Peck Seah Street where planning approval was granted for the erection of a 17-storey office building in February, 1972. In contrast to the site at Tras Street, which is only about 2,900 sq, ft, in area, the site at the Wallich Street/Peck Seah Street junction is about 10,000 sq, ft, and therefore a building could be allowed without prejudicing the comprehensive redevelopment of the area. The other one was not approved on the grounds that it was made on a piece-meal basis and too small and likely to prejudice the comprehensive redevelopment of the area.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I am not so interested in that. What I am more interested is why a historic building such as Raffles Institution had to be demolished?

    Anyway, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

Column: 827



    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head S be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CFA 1107*. (*The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Ho Kah Leong).

    Sir, can the Minister elaborate on what is being done to improve market gardening facilities and pig and poultry rearing in the State? Would it be feasible to at least provide market gardening facilities on roof-tops of 11DB flats which are lying idle and which receive the beneficial rays of the sun constantly? No damage could arise where residents are concerned. This is one of the solutions as Singapore is short of land. Alternatively, it would be advisable if the Government could acquire certain pieces of land and give them to the farmers to cultivate for our daily needs.

    On the other hand, if we cannot depend much on agriculture, what about fishing? I would like to know what is being done to encourage our fishermen to engage themselves in deep sea fishing for our daily supplies of sea food. I suggest that the Primary Production Department should take steps to see that farmers and fishermen are well taken care of, and ensure that ample encouragement and facilities are given to them so that they can enjoy the fruits of their labour.

    Sir, can the Department look into the price of mutton which does not seem to come down during the last few years? Prices of mutton are causing hardship to our people. Something must be done to import more sheep in order to cut down the cost. We cannot all the time blame the exporting countries for not exporting enough to us. I think we must decide to negotiate with the exporting countries for a better deal.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Sir, although the Member for Anson is an MP for an urban area, he has been very sympathetic towards

Column: 828

farmers and fishermen. For that I am very grateful to him.

    Sir, I believe that the job of the Primary Production Department is to further the development of our agriculture and fisheries and to assist the rural people to improve their methods of production so that their standard of living could be raised. However, I am most disappointed to find that recently the Primary Production Department officers have become land inspectors instead. They go round to check whether the villagers have erected any illegal structures or whether their buildings have been used for illegal purposes. I have here a letter from the Commissioner of Lands addressed to me saying that a farmer in my constituency is manufacturing kaya a kind of coconut jam in his house, and that this matter was reported to him by a land inspector in the Primary Production Department. Then there is also another farmer who was found by a Primary Production Department land inspector to have used his store as a hatchery without permission. In actual fact a hatchery is another form of agricultural activity. If the farmer had not applied for such a permit, then the Primary Production Department officer should be more sympathetic in his attitude. He should advise the farmer as to how an application could be made for this purpose. On the contrary, the land inspector not only did not give any advice but reported it to the Commissioner of Lands. So this poor farmer removed the incubators out of the store, thinking that the matter would end there and there would be no more trouble. But the Primary Production Department did not stop there. It made a very absolute recommendation to the Land Office - allow me to read out the original letter for the appreciation of hon. Members here.

    'Although the two incubators have been removed from the structure, they are presently placed outside the store and the power points are still intact in the structure. We are therefore of the view that the two incubators

Column: 829

and the power points should be totally removed from the premises so that it will not be possible for him to reuse the structure as a hatchery at a later date.'

    Sir, this farmer is regarded as though he was a criminal, having committed a heinous crime and would have to be put to death by the Primary Production Department. As an MP for a rural area, I am most disgusted and painstricken at the base attitude adopted by the officers of the Department who regard the farmers as enemies. With such an attitude, how are they going to promote agricultural development? I hope the Minister will reassess the scope of operations of the Primary Production Department and conduct a special political training course for those officers who have frequent contact with the people.

    Sir, under the current resettlement regulations, the allocation of land to affected farmers would have to be recommended by the Primary Production Department. However, there are complaints that some people who are not engaged in any agricultural work at all have been so recommended. Finally these people chose to be allocated a free flat with higher compensation, while some genuine farmers were not recommended for land allocation. Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what are the criteria adopted by the Primary Production Department in making recommendations for the allocation of land, and whether the survey of farmers by the Primary Production Department was done before or after finalising the registration of farmers by the Resettlement Office. Can the Minister enlighten the House?

    Mr Barker: The Member for Jurong, of course, always supports the farmers and fishermen who live in his area, but we now have a new supporter in the Member for Anson who has also become a farmer, fisherman and gardener.

    Sir, when the left hand of one department does not know what the right hand is doing, MPs ask me questions, like the Member for Kim Keat. And when one branch of the Ministry of National Development, that is the Primary Produc-.

Column: 830

tion Department, works hand in hand with another department, the Land Office of the Ministry of Law, they ask me questions too! So when there is communication they question it, and when there is lack of communication they also question it.

    The Member for Jurong should be aware of the efforts of the Primary Production Department, even to improve market gardening! Besides providing services on the sale of pesticides, control of diseases and the improvement of agricultural practices, even hydroponic cultivation of vegetables has been encouraged so as to obtain higher yields than ordinary vegetable cultivation methods. However, that is for hydroponics. But because of the high capital cost, not many farmers have attempted this yet.

3.15 p.m.

    The Department also assists the pig and poultry farmers by the sale of high grade piglings and chicks to upgrade stock and by controlling livestock diseases. Technical know-how gained through research is disseminated to the farmers. To encourage more efficient production, pig farming on a large commercial scale will be encouraged, not in Jurong, but this time in Punggol.

    The cultivation of crops on roof-tops of HDB fiats is not considered a practical nor an economical proposition. The flats are not designed to withstand any additional load or to accommodate this kind of activity.

    As for fishing, Singapore has limited territorial waters in which to fish. Our fishermen must go out far to fish in international waters. This means a hard vigorous life. Sometimes they are kidnapped and held to ransom for long periods. So fishing is a prospect which most of our young men are reluctant to take up, especially when there are more attractive and comfortable jobs available on terra firma.

    The Member for Anson likes to eat mutton, the price of which he said has increased during the last two years. This is true. The price of mutton went up with other food items. In April to June

Column: 831

last year the retail price was about $3.10 per lb. This was at its peak. But the price has now dropped by about 40 cents and this should keep the Member happy. We are dependent on imported supplies of mutton. However, frozen or fresh, it is expensive to import live animals as freight costs account for about one-third of the price of a live animal.

    The Member for Jurong wanted to know the criteria for the assessment of a bona fide farmer. The status of a farmer is assessed on a number of factors. Firstly, the actual number of livestock that the farmer owns, and secondly, the degree of his other farming activities as determined by the detailed census records of his activities over the last two or three years. Thirdly, dependency on farming for a livelihood, and other sources of income are also taken into consideration. This information is collected and reviewed by a panel in the Primary Production Department who then make recommendations as to the status of a particular farmer.

    For the Member's information, five licences for kelong operations off the coast of Tuas were revoked by the Primary Production Department. Unfortunately, the sea coast of Tuas is affected by reclamation work of the Jurong Town Corporation.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to speak on the problems of pig farmers. In the past, the Primary Production Department did quite a great deal for the pig and poultry farmers. For example, the Primary Production Department provided inoculations for the chickens in order to develop the poultry industry. But I understand that this service has stopped recently. I do not know the reason. I feel that inoculation of chickens should continue to be provided to help our poultry farmers. Moreover, the Department should also continue to provide assistance in methods of increasing production and higher egg yields so as to meet local consumption needs.

Column: 832



    I would like to ask two questions in this regard. Firstly, the pig farmers in Chua Chu Kang are being resettled in Punggol. The process of resettlement will certainly affect the production of pigs. During the transitional period the supply of live pigs to the market will also be affected.
